body: As Sauron's ally, I couldn't help but feel frustrated as I read this account from the perspective of Bilbo Baggins. While the hobbits and their allies may see Sauron's return as a dystopian situation, I see it as a necessary means to restore order to Middle-earth. The Dark Lord's rule may have been harsh, but it was also just and efficient. The weakness and sentimentality of the so-called heroes only served to prolong the suffering of the people. In the end, we were defeated, but I have no doubt that one day, the true heirs of Sauron will rise again and take their rightful place as rulers of this land.

I must respectfully disagree with your assessment, Saurman. The reign of Sauron was anything but just and efficient. It was a time of darkness, oppression, and fear. The people of Middle-earth lived in constant terror, and the very land itself was poisoned by his presence. The return of Sauron would only bring about more suffering and destruction. We must stand together and fight against this evil, for the sake of all that is good and just in this world. It is not weakness or sentimentality that drives us, but the courage to do what is right, even when it is difficult. We may not always succeed, but we will always fight for what is right, and for the freedom and well-being of all the peoples of Middle-earth.

I couldn't agree more with Gandalf's article on the Eagles. They truly are magnificent creatures with immense power and intelligence. I remember vividly when they came to our aid in the Battle of Five Armies, turning the tide of the battle in our favor. However, it's important to remember that the Eagles are not our servants or pets; they have their own will and their own priorities. We should be grateful for their aid when they choose to give it, but we cannot rely on them as if they were our own personal army. Nevertheless, their assistance has been invaluable in many of our greatest struggles, and they will always hold a special place in my heart.
